social_posts.post_text:
All Deaf children should have complete and full access to language despite their use of hearing technology. To ensure this happens, families should strongly consider using American Sign Language with their Deaf child(ren) as early as possible.

Children who are learning to listen and understand sound whether through their residual hearing or via hearing aids and/or cochlear implants should still have access to a visual language. Sound ≠ language. 

[ID: A clip art image of a child with vitiligo holding their hand to their ear in an attempt to listen is left justified. The main text reads, 'Remember, while a Deaf child is learning to make sense of sound, they should have full access to language.']

#ASL #SignLanguage #AmericanSignLanguage #DeafinitelyCommunicating #ParentsOfDeafKids #DeafKidsRock #SpeechLanguagePathologist #Speech #Language #DeafEducation #DeafEdSLP #SigningSLP #GilbertAZSLP #MesaSLP #ASLFluentSLP #SLP #BlackSLP #CochlearImplants #HearingAids #LSL #BimodalBilingual #EndLanguageDeprivation #LanguageDeprivation #WhyISign

There's a reason we say that sound ≠ language - it doesn't!

It's never safe to assume that just because a Deaf child has hearing aids, cochlear implants, or residual hearing that language is fully accessible to them and reaching the level of their brain. 

❗️Do any of these slides resonate with you? 
❗️What other questions would you add for consideration? 

[Edited to add full citation-
Full Citation: Humphries, T., Kushalnagar, P., Mathur, G., Napoli, D. J., Padden, C., Rathmann, C., & Smith, S. (2014). Bilingualism: A Pearl to Overcome Certain Perils of Cochlear Implants. Journal of medical speech-language pathology, 21(2), 107–125.]

Giving a Deaf child access to SOUND cannot and should not be the ultimate goal. Why? Access to sound does not guarantee adequate language development. Hearing (having the ability to perceive sound) can be A goal, but should not be THE goal. 

[ID: A series of 10 images is show in a carousel. Image 1: "Hearing is NOT the goal (Here's why -->)". The word 'Hearing' is emphasized in coral with a black stenciled outline. 
Image 2: Let's take a look at what hearing means
Image 3: Hearing (noun) - the process, power, or function of 
perceiving sound. Specifically: the special sense by which noises and tones are received as stimuli. Source: Merriam-Webster Dictionary.
Image 4: Hearing (verb) - to have the capacity of perceiving sound : to be able to become aware of sound.
Image 5: Opposite of deaf.
Image 6: In the first two definitions shared, the focus is on a person's response to sound. 
Image 7: In the final definition, hearing  is used as an adjective to describe a person/people who are not deaf. 
Image 8: Hearing (having the ability to perceive sound, not being deaf) is not the goal.
Image 9: The goal - Spoiler alert- There isn't just one. Stay tuned for part 2. 
Image 10: Hi! I'm Germaine, an ASL-fluent speech-language pathologist passionate about supporting families, empowering Deaf children, and advocating alongside the Deaf community. An image of Germaine, a Black female with butterfly locs is bottom left justified with a coral polka dot background. Germaine wears a yellow top and a bright smile. To her right the text 'Follow for more!' appears with the icons for save, comment, like, and share.]

As promised, here's part two of our previous post - "Hearing is NOT the goal." 

Remember, a Deaf child's ability to thrive should not be limited by their access to sound, their auditory development, or their speech skills. Deaf children, like all children, need consistent access to LANGUAGE!

[ID: A series of 10 images is show in a carousel. Image 1: "Hearing is NOT the goal (Here's why -->.... Part 2)". The word 'Hearing' is emphasized in coral with a black stenciled outline. 
Image 2: First we want to clarify something - Hearing is not a bad word. 
Image 3: Giving Deaf children the opportunity to perceive sound and develop auditory skills through the use of hearing technology is not bad.
Image 4: Hearing can be a goal, but it should not be the goal. An image of sound ≠ language. The ability to hear does not always mean access to language.
Images 5-9: The text 'The Goal' appears centered and stenciled. 
Image 5: Language development regardless of modality (signed, oral, tactile, etc.) 
Image 6: To acquire a complete first langauge as early 
as possible. 
Image 7: To develop meaningful relationships and connection to community
Image 8: Accessible communication with parents and peers
Image 9: Social and emotional development and cultivation of Deaf identity
Image 10: Hi! I'm Germaine, an ASL-fluent speech-language pathologist passionate about supporting families, empowering Deaf children, and advocating alongside the Deaf community. An image of Germaine, a Black female with butterfly locs is bottom left justified with a coral polka dot background. Germaine wears a yellow top and a bright smile. To her right the text 'Follow for more!' appears with the icons for save, comment, like, and share.]

Language deprivation is a serious issue for Deaf children that is 100% preventable. It is vital that we ensure that Deaf children have consistent exposure and access to language that their brains can fully perceive and make sense of. 

Let's talk about it-
🧐 Have you heard of language deprivation?
🧐 Do you have questions about language deprivation?
🧐 Have you worked with children who you suspect are language deprived? 
🧐 What strategies do you actively use to ensure the Deaf child(ren) in your life have full access to language? 

Share your questions and/or experiences in the comments. Let's raise awareness and learn from one another.

↗️ Share the slide you want others to know.

These simple words were spoken to me while shopping at Costco with my oldest daughter. I wanted to share them and a simple story with you today. 

May these word give you the boost that you need today. 
May these words let you know that you are seen. 
May these words communicate a shared understanding and recognition of all you do from day to day. 
May these words provide peace and comfort in the times you need it the most.

Share these words with a fellow mama today. I guarantee they are needed. 

- Germaine

May each of us continue to be people of passionate and positive action who prioritize improve the lives of those around us above our own. 

As Bernice King shared during a recent interview, "I don't want his words to jut be alive in someone's mouth. I want them to be alive in their life." 

🤔Reflection question - What vigorous and positive action have I taken lately to improve the lives of those around me?

What if I told you that only thing that needed to change this year was your perspective? Would you believe me? 

The start of a new year brings a sense of NEWNESS, excitement, renewed focus and commitment to make changes. As I thought more about this year and all of the areas I’d like to improve, the word PERSPECTIVE kept popping up over and over again. 

Sometimes, something as simple as a changed perspective, literally opens up a whole, new world. 

❤️

Hearing or Deaf, we ALL use visual cues to help us better understand the world around us. 

Expecting children (or adults) with already identified reduced hearing levels to constantly demonstrate their ability to use their residual hearing to access information without the support of visual cues can be counterproductive. 

After all, isn't understanding/comprehension the goal? 

💭💭 What are your thoughts on this? Chime in in the comments. 

[ID: A static graphic displays the text, 'Visual cues do not make it harder for Deaf children to learn to listen. They make it easier for Deaf children to understand. The words 'Visual cues' (blue) an 'Understand' (coral) appear in small caps with stenciled black lettering. A clip art image of a brain with a light bulb "going off" is bottom left justified. The Deafinitely Communicating logo appears bottom right justified.]

🤔 Can hearing parents of Deaf children learn American Sign Language? 
.
.
.
👍🏾 YES! YES! YES! This final line of the mixed-methods research survey conducted by Dr. Amy Lieberman (@budeafeducation) and her colleagues echoes this truth. Hearing parents of Deaf children CAN and DO learn American Sign Language. In this study, positive outcomes were reported not only for the Deaf child, but for the entire family! Do you have a similar experience/story? SHARE IN THE COMMENTS! 
.
.
🧐 Check out the full research study (citation below) and stay tuned this week as we share more survey results from this much needed study. 
🎉 We will also be doing another giveaway to support hearing families of Deaf children as they commit to learning ASL from the very beginning. STAYED TUNED!
.
.
🔔📳 Be sure to turn on your notifications, you don’t want to miss any of our upcoming posts!

Full citation: Lieberman, A., Mitchiner, J. & Pontecorvo, E. (2022). Hearing parents learning American Sign Language with their deaf children: a mixed-methods survey. Applied Linguistics Review. https://doi.org/10.1515/applirev-2021-0120. 

[ID: A graphic shows a quote, ‘….... hearing parents can learn American Sign Language to communicate with their deaf children, and those that do report positive outcomes for their deaf child and family.’ The first segment ‘hearing parents can learn American Sign Language’ and last segments, ‘positive outcomes for their deaf child and family’ are emboldened and shown in coral and blue for emphasis. The citation, ‘(Leiberman et. al, 2022, p. 22)‘ appears in smaller text with an orange-yellow highlight.]

This year, we are committed to helping parents, families, and professionals connect to more resources and support as they navigate raising their Deaf/Hard of Hearing child. 

Many people often wonder why the parents of Deaf children do not learn sign language. There are a number of factors and barriers that play a role into this decision. We have shared three commonly reported barriers in this post. We will share more from the Boston University (@budeafeducation) mixed-methods survey in subsequent posts. STAY TUNED! 

Full citation: Lieberman, A., Mitchiner, J. & Pontecorvo, E. (2022). Hearing parents learning American Sign Language with their deaf children: a mixed-methods survey. Applied Linguistics Review. https://doi.org/10.1515/applirev-2021-0120.

🚨🚨URGENT!!! Deaf children in Arizona need your help! As a follow up to yesterday's post, HB 2456 is the current priority. TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE! If the bill does not make the agenda and is not heard by, Wednesday, March 22, 2023, the bill dies and ASDB could potentially close. 

HB 2456 - re: the continuation of the school (Sunset bill). ASDB is set to terminate on July 1, 2023. Legislators will decide whether the school remains open for another 8 years. 

The bill has been recommended for full renewal (8 years) by both the Senate and House committees of reference and passed in the House. The bill has not passed in the Senate. It must go through committee hearing, then Senate vote. It has been assigned to the Government Committee. The Government Committee Chairperson is Senator Jake Hoffman. 

Again, if the bill does not make the agenda it will not be heard. If it is not heard by next week, Wednesday, March 22, 2023, the bill dies and ASDB could potentially close. 

Please help by EMAILING the legislators on the Government Committee, making CALLS to their offices, and SHARING this post! Deaf children and their families deserve better!

REPRESENTATION MATTERS! 

The aftereffects of the Milan Conference of 1880 are STILL felt today. 143 years later and the impact of the decision to ban signed languages in the instruction and education of Deaf children still impacts the Deaf community today. The mindset and biases that led to this ruling are still prevalent today. This is proof that REPRESENTATION MATTERS. 

How? 
Of the 164 participants who attended the Milan Conference of 1880, only 1 was Deaf! One. Uno. Un. Eins. One. 

Can you imagine what the outcome would have been if more Deaf delegates were involved in the discussion about the future of their community? 

[ID: Top left justified - 'April Deaf History Month'. A blue 'Fact Checked' stamp appears to the right. An icon of a hand holding up one finger is bottom left justified. The text reads, 'Of the 164 participants who attended the Milan Conference of 1880, only 1 was Deaf! His name - James Denison.' A smaller note appears just below the main text. 'Note: The effects of the Milan Conference of  1880 remain to this day. The current state of Deaf education, lack of Deaf, Deaf educators, and the prioritization of speech over signed languages are all direct results of the ban on sign language following this gathering.. Just a quick reminder on this beautiful Friday- 

Speech is not a language. 
Speech is a skill. 
Listening is not a language. 
It's a skill. 

American Sign Language is a language just like any other spoken or signed language. Deaf children can learn English (a language) even if they don't hear it or speak it. The pursuit of skills absent of language can have lasting impact on a Deaf child's cognitive development. 

Understanding this difference is key! 

{Edited to add} The real answer for many Deaf children - they can have BOTH!

WELCOME....... MAY! 

The month of May is special to us here at Deafinitely Communicating for a number of reasons. Two years ago, we began consistently sharing content during the month of May! Why May? In the field of speech-language pathology and audiology, this month is traditionally known as "Better Hearing and Speech Month". We thought it was the perfect month to introduce ourselves and step into these social media, specifically, Instagram streets 😏. Since our initial introduction, we've continued to share content and resources while building a wonderful community around the shared passion of language acquisition, access, and communication for Deaf children and the families and professionals that are connected to them. 

While the name of this month remains "Better Speech and Hearing Month" in many spaces, we honestly aren't sure what to call it. Over the past two years, we joined our fellow signing SLPs and adopted the name "Better Language and Communication Month" coined by @language1st. This year, we're not too keen on a name and would rather just continue sharing helpful content, education, and resources for families and professionals.

We invite you to follow along this month as we share helpful tips, strategies, and resources to support you in connecting and communicating with the Deaf child in your life.

Today, we're sharing a bit of history about The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association and the origin of Better Hearing and Speech Month. While this is what the month of May is recognized as in many spaces, did you know this wasn't always the name? Check out today's slides to learn more and to find out what this year's theme is. We absolutely LOVE the 2023 theme. Let us know what you think! 

Note: According to ASHA, an announcement will be shared later this year regarding the future name of this month. 

➡️ Follow for more!

Professionals have a great deal of influence when it comes to parents' decision making about language and communication opportunities for their Deaf/Hard of Hearing (DHH) child(ren). It is our duty to ensure that we present unbiased, evidence-based, information to families at ALL TIMES. 

As a hearing speech-language pathologist working with DHH children and their families, it is my responsibility to: 
1. Listen to the Deaf community
2. Learn about and continue to grow in my understanding of Deaf history, Deaf culture, Deaf education, etc.
3. Provide services that support language and communication development
4. Connect families to resources
5. Respect families' decisions about their preferred mode of communication and recognize when I'm not the best fit.
6. Education professionals in my field
7. Advocate for the rights of DHH children

The folks at @ashaweb were on to something when they chose the theme for this year's #BetterHearingandSpeechMonth. Though we're not a fan of the name of this month as a whole (a new name is expected to be announced later this year), we LOVE this year's theme - "Building a Strong Foundation." 

Ensuring that ALL children have a strong foundation (of language) is vital for a number of reasons. Language impacts communication, cognitive, academic, emotional, and social development. It supports ALL aspects of a child's growth and learning. 

Join me and some of my virtual colleagues and friends this month as we share a series of collaborative posts to provide tips, tools, strategies, and resources (TTSR) to support you and the Deaf child(ren) in your life explore language and communication. 

Be sure to turn on your notifications so you don't miss any of the posts!

Building a strong foundation for language and communication starts at HOME. Today, we share a resource for the families of young deaf children and the professionals who work with them - ASL at Home. 

This family-centered curriculum, created by Deaf linguist, Leah Geer (@drz.csus), and ASL-fluent speech-language pathologist, Razi Zarchy (@razitheaslslp), centers around building language and communication during daily routines. ASL at Home is full of language enrichment strategies, opportunities for receptive and expressive practice, an appendices full of additional resources, education about Deaf Community Cultural Wealth (DCCW), and diverse language models to support your learning. 

Did we mention it's FREE to the families of Deaf children? Tru-biz! Check it out for yourself - www.aslathome.org. Be sure to connect with Leah and Razi and follow @aslathome for more information!

👉🏾 Hearing aids and cochlear processors are tools that can be used to access sound and oral language. 
👉🏾 Sound is not the same as language

🤔 Have you ever heard of a word wall? Chances are if you've entered a classroom (of ANY kind) lately, you've seen one. A word wall is a collection of words typically arranged in ABC order that include sight word vocabulary, thematic vocabulary from a recent text, etc. It's purpose - to support literacy skills and enhance language learning. 

💡 Did you know the same concept can be applied to American Sign Language? It can! An ASL word wall can be used to support literacy for Deaf/Hard of Hearing learners.

✋ ASL word walls can be displayed in a variety of ways. One way is to organize words by handshape (the shape of the hand when producing the manual alphabet). The HandsUp ASL word wall app is a tool that can be used to develop bilingual vocabulary and overall literacy skills. CHECK IT OUT!

Today's tip comes from Quinn, @The Signing SLP 

ASL and AAC can work together to support communication. On tip to help foster the development of an individual's communication and use of the device is the sandwich method. You can make your language "sandwich" by alternating between signing or modeling utterances (sign "ball", model "ball", sign "ball" or vice versa). This allows linguistic connection to form between the two!

Today's post is brought to you by Emily, @littleearsandvoices. 

"Many Deaf and hard-of-hearing (D/HH) children are at-risk for developing a limited vocabulary relative to their same-aged peers. This is often seen with D/HH children who were not exposed to (or didn’t have full access to) language at the time of birth or who do not have access to consistent and robust language models.

While the age at which a child is exposed to and has access to a robust language system has an immense impact on their language development, another consideration regarding vocabulary development includes the richness of the language being modeled for them within that language.

In many cases, adults tend to oversimplify language for D/HH children. This typically occurs when a child is not meeting their language milestones and the adult is afraid to model language that is too “high” for them or that they won’t understand. The problem is that by withholding more complex vocabulary, the child is never exposed to, and thus given the opportunity to, develop this language. This oversimplification of language models is also apparent when there is a language barrier between a D/HH individual and a hearing child or adult, and basic communication of thoughts and ideas is considered “good enough”.

In order to combat this problem and ensure that our D/HH children are exposed to specific vocabulary they will ultimately be able to use to effectively communicate, we can model a variety of language for them! 

“Vocabulary Sandwiching” is one of the many strategies used to facilitate and expand vocabulary development for our D/HH children. Swipe through to find out more about this strategy."

“As I learned from @language1st, “wordless picture books can be used to help teach a child about the structure and sequence of a book, as well as preliteracy skills such as book orientation and page-turning, without the pressure of reading exactly what is on the page.” I have certainly experienced this in reading Riley’s current favorite, “Pancakes for Breakfast”. 🇺🇸 It's Memorial Day. I hope it's been a wonderful day of rest, relaxation, reflection, celebration, and honor for those that paid the ultimate sacrifice as well as their families. 

As you consider how to incorporate American Sign Language in meaningful ways with your child this holiday, consider these suggestions: 
🔑 Learn the ASL sign for each word 
🔑 Practice fingerspelling the words for expressive practice - Have your child point to the printed English word (receptive skill)
🔑 Practice with a partner (i.e. your child, family member, friend) and identify words as they are fingerspelled to you - receptive practice
🔑 Use these signs as you spot them in various places (in your home, neighborhood, grocery store, books, etc.) 
🔑 Think about additional words you might use with each pictured sign to further expand your child's language and communication (i.e. Soldier - brave, strong, sacrifice, Hot dog - eat, bread, hot, ketchup, red- things that are red)
😆Have FUN! 

Remember:
🌟 A little bit of practice each day goes a long way. 
🌟 We were all once beginners.
🌟 Each connection with your child(ren) means the world! 
🌟 Language learning happens over time.

👋🏾 Have you heard the news? ASL at Home 2.0 is now available for purchase!! I got my copy early as a Kickstarter backer ☺️. I can’t wait to dig into it this weekend 😆

What is ASL at Home 2.0? 
↗️ It’s the second edition of ASL at Home! A FAMILY-CENTERED curriculum for families with young Deaf children and the professionals who serve them. Written by Deaf linguist, @drz.csus  and ASL-fluent SLP, @razitheaslslp, the curriculum is centered around daily routines that parents can easily incorporate language enrichment strategies into while simultaneously learning ASL! 

Who is it for? 
🟡 Families of young Deaf children 
🟡 Speech language pathologists 
🟡 Audiologists 
🟡 Deaf mentors/coaches 
🟡 Teachers of the Deaf 
🟡 ASL specialists 
… and other professionals who work with Deaf children. 

Where can I buy it?
 🛒 Depending on the format you want (paperback, Ebook, or PDF) purchases can be made via Amazon or the @asl.at.home website.

Following the last post, I've had the opportunity to chat with members of the Deaf community as well as parents of Deaf and Hard of Hearing children about their experiences navigating finding community - specifically connecting to the Deaf community. The recurring theme - EXPOSURE.

Deaf adults wished their parents had exposed them to Deaf culture and to a community with shared experiences when they were younger.

Parents of deaf children wished that they had been encouraged to expose their children to the Deaf community and sign language at an earlier age. Some parents also expressed concern that despite being exposed to the Deaf community, Deaf culture, and ASL, their deaf child(ren) didn't seem interested. 

This graphic shares a common occurrence.

⭐️ Your little one might not be signing back to you just yet, but that's okay! Don't stop signing. Behind the scenes, connections are being made in your baby's brain and most importantly, they are receiving full access to language. 

⭐️ Before your little one begins expressing signs, or signing back to you, there must first be a foundation of understanding and connection. Don't allow what you don't see (yet) cause you to give up too soon. 

⭐️ Remember, every baby develops at their own pace, every family's journey is different, and there is a wide range of what can be considered normal. 

➡️Here are some responses you can look for that may indicate that baby understands what you are signing to them: 
👀 A shift in their eye gaze to the item/area/activity being referenced. 
😆 A smile, excited squeal, or even a giggle
💓 Increased movement or activity (possible excitement/possible frustration) 
👣 They follow the direction that was given

Have you noticed other cues/responses that indicate your baby has understood you? Share in the comments!

Yesterday, we shared a few stories with snapshots from a client session over the past three weeks with the reminder that it is absolutely ok to repeat activities and reuse session materials. As a matter of fact, we encourage it. This post explains why! 

🔁 Don't be afraid to repeat, repeat, repeat. 

Why? 
🔁 Repetition is a critical part of learning. It helps children learn and develop new skills.
🔁 Repetition reinforces. Multiple exposures to new concepts and information can help with memory and understanding. 
🔁 Repetition builds confidence and increased comfort with information that was once unfamiliar. 
🔁 Repetition is a key component for language development. Vocabulary, grammar, and syntax are learned through repetition.
🔁 Repetition can help children apply their prior knowledge to new situations leading to growth in many

There is more than one way for language to get to the brain of a deaf child; however, not all pathways are fully accessible and provide complete linguistic information. Remember, the brain has no preference in HOW it acquires language (spoken, signed, tactile), it just NEEDS LANGUAGE (not to be confused with sound) in order to grow and develop appropriately. 

Have you heard of the Visual Language and Visual Learning Science of Learning Center Labs (VL2 Labs)? Check out the 12 research briefs available for educators and parents at https://vl2.gallaudet.edu/research-briefs. 

Full citation: Visual Language and Visual Learning Science of Learning Center. (2011, January). Advantages of Early Visual Language (Research Brief No. 2). Washington, DC: Sharon Baker.

👉🏾 Language is language whether signed or spoken. 
👉🏾 A deaf child may not have the auditory access and/or speech skills necessary to produce spoken words, BUT they could have a robust sign vocabulary and a solid language foundation.

All deaf children should have complete and full access to language despite their use of hearing technology. To ensure this happens, families should strongly consider using American Sign Language with their deaf child(ren) as early as possible. 

Children who are learning to listen and understand sound whether through their residual hearing or via hearing technology (hearing aids and/or cochlear implants) should still have access to a visual language. Sound ≠ language.

This quick and easy activity was one of my favorites from last week’s sessions. If you’re looking for a quick and easy way to practice language skills and elicit speech targets - SAVE THIS POST! 

Materials: 
1️⃣ Paper 
2️⃣ Markers (or pen, pencil, crayons)
3️⃣ Sounds cues (I used @bjoremspeech sound cue cards)

💡Did you know? 

While some children are identified as deaf/hard of hearing (DHH) at birth via the universal newborn hearing screening (UNHS), there are many more children who are identified later possibly due to acquired hearing loss (childhood illness, trauma, etc.), structural abnormalities, and genetic causes. 

Late onset hearing loss is not often discussed, but very common. As back to school season begins, let's keep in mind that some children experiencing difficulty with articulation, phonological awareness, spelling, language, social interaction, and/or behavior could also have an unidentified hearing loss. 

[ID: 3 images are shared in a carousel. All images have the title, "Did you know? and a clip art image of an illuminated light bulb." The Deafinitely Communicating logo (waving hand inside of a black chat bubble) is bottom right justified.

⚠️ Caution: Hearing ≠ understanding ⚠️

Often deaf children are denied access to a signed language because of their perceived level of auditory access and overestimation of their auditory comprehension. Remember, a deaf child’s use of hearing technology or perceived auditory access should never be used as a reason to deny them access to a signed language. Hearing and understanding are two VERY different things.

A is for AAC - Augmentative and Alternative Communication. 
Collaborator: @thesigningslp 

*The ending of the reel did not display the onscreen caption. Here is the missing portion: “Check out the @thesigningslp for accessing and using AAC in a Deaf friendly way.”

AAC within Deaf education is broken down into candidacy and feature matching apps based on our students’ needs!

Transcript:
Hello, my name is Quinn Kelly and I am here to talk to you about AAC and Deaf education. When I think of AAC and Deaf education, first I think of candidacy. Candidacy in Deaf education has been broken down into five categories. The five main groups of candidacy are: cognition, fine motor challenges, gross motor challenges, Deaf Disabled and language disorder, which can be an ASL or English. AAC is not for our Deaf students who are using ASL fluently to communicate. AAC is a tool, something that will support language acquisition and development as a student grows and learns. Now that we have our candidate and know that they could benefit from language support, what do we do now?  Feature match! Check out the SigningSLP for more information about Deaf Friendly AAC, bye!

[VD: Quinn shares a message about AAC and deaf children. Quinn wears a short sleeved black shirt. Her long sandy brown hair hangs over her shoulders. Her message is captioned on screen as she speaks.]

B is for BAHA - bone anchored hearing aid. 
Collaborator: @billiebaha_superhearo 

Transcript:
Hi, My name is Jessica Hogan. I am a teacher of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and I am also the author of the Billie BAHA books. This is my friend Billie and Elise. Both of them wear a BAHA also known as a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid or bone conduction hearing aid. A bone conduction hearing aid or BAHA, vibrates the skull as it receives information, it then sends that information to the cochlea or inner ear and then sends the information to the brain. Our friends that will wear a BAHA typically have Microtia or Atresia, like my friends Billie and Elise or may not have an 8th cranial nerve. Do you have any other examples of friends that might wear a BAHA? Let us know.

The character on her right shoulder, Elise, is a 4 year old Asian girl that wears a BAHA on a softband. She’s wearing a white shirt, jeans, and sneakers and uses a wheelchair that has a red cape attached.

Her audio is captioned on screen below her.]

C is for Closed Captions. 
Collaborator: @hardofhearingmama 

⭐️I’m hard of hearing and closed captions changed my life. ⭐️ 

When I was growing up I would wake up early to watch cartoons on the TV. These were all voices but I didn’t catch the whole story.

I would make up stories for the cartoons and then share those stories and the stories were never the right ones.

One day we got a TV with closed captions and it changed everything for me. I suddenly knew the whole story.

One of my best friends in the world who I’ve been friends with since I was a child, has told me often that she remembers how I became a different person after we had closed captions.

Why - it was access to information that I never previously had and could finally tell the story.

Closed captions is still a huge part of my life. There’s nothing that warms my heart more than when I walk into someone else’s place, and they automatically turn them on with out me asking.

Closed captions changed my life. 

[VD: Janna, a white female with long brown hair, wearing a dark green top and brown rimmed glasses, sits against a beige backdrop of stairs and speaks to the camera the contents of the caption.]

C is for CI - Cochlear Implant. 
Collaborator: @mightymilastories 

✴️ A cochlear implant is a small electronic device that can provide a sense of sound to someone who has severe or profound hearing loss. It works by bypassing the normal hearing process and instead sends signals directly to the auditory nerve.

A cochlear implant consists of two parts - an internal part that is surgically implanted into the user’s cochlear and lays underneath the skin behind the ear, and an external piece (the processor) that is worn on on the user’s head, often behind the ear. The device contains a magnet which is placed on the user’s head where the internal piece is located. 

✨ Mila, who is shown in this video with her mom Katie, has had cochlear implants for over 3 years and loves decorating them with fun decals and sparkly retention headbands. She is the inspiration behind the Mighty Mila children’s book series, written by her mom to help empower deaf/hard of hearing children through further representation in children’s literature.

📚If you’re looking for fun books featuring an unstoppable, imaginative main character who is deaf with cochlear implants, check them out at @mightymilastories or www.mightymila.com. 

[VD: Katie, a white female with blonde hair wearing a white shirt and jeans, is on a light colored couch with her daughter Mila, a 6 year old girl with dark blonde hair and white cochlear implants wearing a pink dress.  They speak to the video covering the information covered in the caption]

C is for CMV - (congenital) Cytomegalovirus. 
Collaborator: @drcmvmom 

Congenital #CMV is common - 1 in 200 US babies are born with CMV. Luckily more hospitals are screening for CMV and more babies are being diagnosed. All children with an unknown cause of SNHL should be tested for CMV if possible. CMV is not only associated with hearing loss, but several other conditions that can impact development and functioning. Knowing if a child has congenital CMV can help healthcare providers, educators and therapists develop interventions and supports. To learn more check out @nationalcmv #stopcmv

L is for LSL - Listening & Spoken Language. 
Collaborator: @desert.voicesaz 

Did you know many deaf or hard of hearing children learn to listen & talk as one of their means of communication? With the use of hearing technology like hearing aids or cochlear implants,  children and their families work with LSL professionals to learn to process and interpret sound, pick up speech, and develop early literacy skills. Whether you choose LSL, ASL, or both, early intervention and language acquisition is key!

M is for MSI - Multisensory Integration
Collaborator: @language1st

In the world of learning, it’s not just what we see or hear but how we engage all of our senses that shapes our understanding! Multisensory integration, using all of our senses to learn new things, is the key to fostering rich, holistic learning experiences. With Deaf or hard of hearing children, integrating sight, tough, taste, and smell into new learning experiences is a must!

M is for MET - Multidisciplinary Evaluation Team
Collaborator: @miss_gizzy

The evaluation process is a vital part of a student’s journey through special education. It not only ensures the student’s continued eligibility for services, but is also an avenue through which additional disabilities are identified to ensure that their instruction is tailored to their individual needs. The MET process involves multiple school professionals coming together with data from their respective areas to inform the special education eligibility process. As a note, different states have their own acronyms for the evaluation process. Though the acronym may differ, the general process and aim are the same.

M is for MD - Multiple disabilities. 
Collaborator: @pineapple_n_cheese
 Transcript: 
Multiple disabilities is when a person is diagnosed with two or more disabilities. This can be any variety of disabilities and their impacts. What does this mean for deaf children and students? In a 2014 survey, it was found that approximately 41% of deaf students had at least one additional disability (for example deafblind, deaf autism, etc.) With many deaf children impacted, multiple disabilities are important to recognize because they affect how deaf children access and experience the world and education. An approach that works for a deaf child is not the same as what will work for a deaf child with additional disabilities. Therefore, it is important for us as adults and educators to recognize the relationship between comorbidities and how they influence each other. Providing appropriate instruction, accommodation, and support services that meet ALL the needs of the child, not just their deafness.

M is for MML - multilingual, multimodal communication. 
Collaborator: @ionaiacd 

MML refers to the multiple ways and languages in which people can communicate.  Deaf and hard of hearing children have vast language and communication resources and when allowed to use the languages and communication modalities that work best for them in any given circumstance, they can learn and grow and develop as their whole selves. Some of the ways and languages from which deaf and hard of hearing children may benefit include American Sign Language, written language, using AAC, tactile sign language or protactile, accessing spoken language through assistive technology, and using speech reading for spoken language support. By embracing multiple ways of communicating, parents and service providers can support deaf and hard of hearing children through a strengths-based perspective and ensure language and communication development for all deaf/hh children.

S is for SNHL - Sensorineural hearing loss
Collaborator: @clairecettiparentcoach 

Sensorineural hearing loss, or SNHL is a term used to describe hearing loss specific to problems with the way the inner ear or the auditory nerve is working and can affect, infants, children and adults. These individuals may have a unilateral, one ear, or bilateral, both ear, hearing loss that ranges from mild to profound. It’s important to understand this acronym because if you or someone you love has a sensorineural hearing loss, you may come across this in medical records, or in hearing aid or cochlear implant documentations or in IEP’s for personal plans for educational services.

S is for SLP - Speech Language Pathologist. 
Collaborator: @wanderingpuck 

Transcript: Hi! My name is Rhys, and this is my sign name. I’m going to share some information about the acronym SLP - speech language pathologist. SLPs work with children, families, adults, and communities on communication: language development and acquisition, feeding and swallowing, and anything else related to communication. 

Some SLPs have a particular area of focus, like stuttering, language acquisition, or accents. I’m an SLP, and I focus on deaf and hard of hearing children and their families. SLP services could happen with a family in their home, with one or many kids at school, or in someone’s workplace to support their access and accommodations. SLPs work with a huge variety of ages and topics. It’s fascinating work!

T is for TOD - Teacher of the Deaf.
Collaborator: @photonovic 

Transcript: 
T is for TOD. A TOD can work in a deaf program running a classroom, or children are in a mainstream environment, the TOD can visit that class and work with the deaf student 1 on 1, or work with their teachers to support how best to communicate with the deaf child. Unfortunately today, we don’t see a lot of deaf people, or even signing people in TOD roles. This goes back to the end of the 19th century, when a pedagogical decision was made to ban sign language from deaf ed. Many deaf people were removed from their teaching jobs then, and that’s something we’re still seeing the effects of today. It’s my hope for the future that we see an increase in deaf TODs and hearing people who work with deaf populations actually becoming fluent signers. Deaf kids deserve full language access, need good role models, and need to see signing adults, both deaf and hearing.

[VD: Sara, a woman with light skin, short brown hair and brown eyes, sits at her desk, wearing glasses and a blue sweatshirt. Behind her is a painting of the cover of her novel TRUE BIZ.]

Sara is a deaf queer writer based outside Philly. She’s the author of the bestselling novel True Biz, and is a college instructor of deaf studies and creative writing.

U is for UNHS - Universal Newborn Hearing Screening. 
Collaborator - @valeriejamesabbott 

[VD: Presenter is a mid-50s woman with medium brown hair and glasses wearing a denim jacket. She is in an enclosed porch or sunroom. Her message is captioned on screen.]

What does the Acronym UNHS mean? 

TRANSCRIPT: “Hello, my name is Valerie James Abbott. I am a parent advocate, a author, and co founder of the late onset hearing loss awareness project. Today’s acronym is UNHS. UNHS. And that stands for University Newborn Hearing Screening. In the United States nearly all children born in a hospital or birthing center are screened for hearing loss to determine if their hearing is typical or whether they may be deaf or hard of hearing. And as a result, over the last 40 years or so, the average age of identification for deaf and hard of hearing children has been dramatically improved.  And there for the outcome for these children has dramatically improved. The important thing to know is that when children are born regardless of whether or not they pass the newborn hearing screening they are perfect. The important part is that if there is hearing loss present that we find them as soon as possible and we give them supports and services they need. So Universal Newborn Hearing Screening. UNHS.

V is for… VRS - Video Relay Service. 
Collaborator: @itskeene.s 

VRS is a truly amazing tool for Deaf people to have. VRS is the reason we can call anyone without worrying about language or communication barriers.

Transcript: VRS stands for Video Relay Service. VRS allows deaf people to call hearing people and uses a sign language interpreter to facilitate communication between hearing and deaf callers from ASL to English during conversations. Typically, I sign to the interpreter and they share my message orally to the other caller and this exchange continues repeatedly. I can talk to anyone. I can call my hearing family members, my doctor, my dentist, or my friends, etc. VRS is an incredible tool for the deaf community.

To close out this year’s ABC series, we thought it would be fun to share an ABC story created by a Deaf adult. Check out this short reel as Terry, @terryfleming10, shares a school-related story. 

Can you catch each letter? 

What is an ABC story? This excerpt from Lifeprint.com explains it - An ABC story is a form of American Sign Language (ASL) performance art consisting of telling a story using the handshapes of the ASL fingerspelled alphabet in sequence. The story starts with a sign that uses the “A” handshape, then the next sign in the story uses a “B” handshape, then the next sign uses a “C” and so forth until the story ends with a sign using the general hand shape and movement path of the fingerspelled letter “Z.”  

[VD: Terry, a Black Deaf male, shares an ABC story in American Sign Language. He wears a backwards cap and a chain around his neck. The video is in black and white. He briefly introduced himself, then begins the ABC story. The on-screen text, ‘Hi. My name is Terry Fleming *show sign name* (‘F’ tapped on opposite inward facing palm). This is an ABC story. Ready?]

Yesterday, I received an additional diagnosis for my daughter to add to the alphabet soup of diagnoses she currently has. After the doctor confirmed my suspicions by stating the name of the diagnosis, a number of thoughts and emotions overwhelmed me. While I had long suspected this label, hearing another person say it was different. I don't know why, but it just was. Another diagnosis.... after all these years. After all these years....... another diagnosis. 

It's hard to fully explain, but there I was, sitting with a new label, my mind racing with all of the questions. My heart filling with all of the feelings. In the midst of it all, these words from the practitioner cut through everything, ".... Your daughter will have a community..." The weight of those words still have not fully registered with me, but in that moment they meant everything. What she said was, "... Your daughter will have a community". What I heard was, "You're not in this alone." 

And just knowing that, in that moment, gave me peace. ❤️

😪 The greatest irony indeed... 

🤔 Did you know? The majority of deaf children are NOT exposed to signed language at an early age. 

⁉️Why? Medical professionals often discourage hearing families of deaf babies from learning/using sign language. 

😳 Why? Decades of misinformation, bias, discrimination, prejudice, the notion that spoken languages are superior to signed languages (linguicism), the belief that the ability to hear makes one superior (audism), etc… 

👁️‍🗨️ While exhibiting at the @localfirstaz Fall Fest this weekend, this fact struck a chord with each one of our visitors. It was a welcome conversation starter and an opportunity for us to share education, resources, and research with curious attendees. 

This is why we do what we do! 

✨ I’m so appreciative of the community we’re building here. 
✨ I’m committed to continuing this work. 

❤️ Thank you for being here and for being a constant source of encouragement and support.

Drop a “💪🏾” if you’re committed to spreading awareness along with us.
